question: Identify the scientific name of sea pen that belongs to phylum Cnidaria. SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Pennatula. Sea pens are colonial marine cnidarians that have a feather-like appearance and are found in deep-sea environments. Gorgonia (Sea-fan) is the genus of a type of soft coral, also in phylum Cnidaria. Adamsia is a genus of sea anemones. Obelia is a genus of colonial hydroids, also in phylum Cnidaria.

question: What is the scientific name of the banyan tree, a large evergreen tree of Asia characterised by its trunk-like aerial roots? SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Ficus benghalensis : Family - Moraceae, Order - Rosales, Kingdom - Plantae. Gossypium herbaceum : Levant cotton. Santalum album : Indian Sandalwood. Ananas comosus : Pineapple.

question: Match the columns. Column-A (Class) Column-B (Common name) i. Chlorophyceae a. Brown algae ii. Phaeophyceae b. Green algae iii. Rhodophyceae c. Blue-green algae iv. Cyanophyceae d. Red algae SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (1st shift)

options.A: i - b, ii - c, iii - a, iv - d
options.B: i - b, ii - a, iii - d, iv - c
options.C: i - d, ii - c, iii - b, iv - a
options.D: i - a, ii - b, iii - c, iv - d

solution.correct_answer: B. i - b, ii - a, iii - d, iv - c
solution.explanation: i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. Divisions of Algae and their Main Characteristics : Chlorophyceae (Green algae) : Major pigments - Chlorophyll, Stored Food - Starch, Ex - Spirogyra. Phaeophyceae (Brown algae) : Pigment - fucoxanthin, Stored food - Mannitol, Laminarin, Ex - Sargassum, Laminaria. Rhodophyceae (Red algae) : Pigment - Phycoerythrin, Stored Food - Floridean starch, Ex - Gracilaria and Gelidium. Cyanophyceae are prokaryotic and play a significant role in nitrogen fixation.

question: Which of the following is another name for starch found mainly in the pulp of seeds, fruits, tubers, roots and stems of plants, especially in corn, potatoes, wheat and rice? SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Amylum - A polymeric carbohydrate consisting of numerous glucose units joined by glycosidic bonds. Olestra (Olean) - Fat substitute that doesn't add any calories to products. Saponins - They are naturally occurring compounds that are widely distributed in all cells of legume plants. Xanthan (polysaccharide) produced from simple sugars using a fermentation process. Uses - common food additive, thickening agent, emulsifier, and stabiliser that prevents ingredients from separating.

question: What is the common term for Ancylostoma? SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Hookworm. Ancylostoma is a genus of parasitic nematodes (roundworms) that primarily infect mammals. These worms are intestinal parasites and are transmitted to humans through contact with contaminated soil or sand where the larvae are present. Tapeworm : genus - Taenia, Examples - Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) and Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm). Filaria worms belong to the family Filarioidea.

question: Solanum lycopersicum L. is the scientific name of which of the following highly consumed vegetables? SSC CHSL 30/05/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Tomato. Tomato is a major contributor of lycopene and is also a considerable source of vitamins K, A, C, fiber, and carbohydrates, besides some amounts of iron, potassium, phosphorus, and sulfur. Potato - Solanum tuberosum, Onion - Allium cepa, and Garlic - Allium sativum.

question: What is the common name of Parthenium hysterophorus? SSC CHSL 01/06/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Carrot Grass. This plant causes milk disease in livestock and is also responsible for respiratory malfunction in humans. Lemon grass - Cymbopogon, Lawn Grass - Poaceae, Horsetails - Equisetum.

question: Oleo gum resin (Asafoetida) can be obtained from: SSC CHSL 06/06/2022 (Morning)

options.A: dried latex from the stem of ferula
options.B: dried latex from the roots of mango
options.C: dried latex from the banana leaves
options.D: dried latex from the tap root of ferula

solution.correct_answer: D. dried latex from the tap root of ferula

question: Which food is a good source of complete protein ? SSC MTS 16/10/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Eggs. Proteins, made of about 20 amino acids, are essential for building muscles, bones, enzymes, and hormones. Protein-rich foods include poultry, seafood, fish, eggs, and dairy products like milk, yogurt, and cheese. Eggs are naturally rich in vitamin B2 (riboflavin), vitamin B12, vitamin D, selenium and iodine.

question: If the Glycemic Index (GI) of a specific food is from 70 to 100, then the type of that food is: SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: High-GI food causes a rapid increase in blood sugar levels after consumption. These foods are typically processed or refined carbohydrates, like white bread or sugary snacks. Foods with a GI of 55 or lower are classified as low-GI, and those with a GI between 56 and 69 are considered medium-GI.

question: Which is the most important protein component in milk, both quantitatively and nutritionally, that accounts for about 80% of the total protein in bovine milk ? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Casein. It exists in milk in complex groups of molecules called micelles. Pepsin converts proteins into proteoses and peptides (peptides). The

question: Which of the following is another name for vitamin C ? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C), a water-soluble vitamin, aids collagen production, wound healing, and bone formation. Its deficiency causes scurvy with symptoms like bleeding gums and delayed healing. Found in citrus fruits (lemons, oranges) and others like strawberries and amla. Types of vitamins include A (Retinol), B1 (Thiamine), B6 (Pyridoxine), E (Tocopherol), and K (Phytonadione).

question: Which essential amino acid enhances calcium absorption and also plays an important role in the formation of collagen? SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Lysine is an essential amino acid that must be obtained from food sources like meat, fish, dairy, and eggs. Collagen contains hydroxylysine, derived from lysine. Amino acids are classified as acidic, basic, or neutral. L-arginine helps build proteins, histidine is essential for protein biosynthesis, and tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid found in proteins and freely in organisms.

question: Which non-essential amino acid is synthesised by the hydroxylation of phenylalanine in a reaction catalysed by phenylalanine hydroxylase ? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Tyrosine. Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins. When proteins are broken down, amino acids are released. It facilitates various bodily functions such as: breaking down food, repairing tissues, and supporting overall growth and maintenance. Essential amino acids are: histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, and valine. Non-essential amino acids are: alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, proline, serine, and tyrosine.

question: Which vitamin is involved in red blood cell formation, neurological function and DNA synthesis ? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Vitamin B12. Vitamins (scientific name) and function: Vitamin B1 (Thiamin) - Growth and development. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) - Red cell production. Vitamin B3 (Niacin) - Healthy skin, digestion and nervous system. Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) - Maintenance of ligaments, tendons. Vitamin K (Phylloquinone) - Clotting of blood. Vitamin E (Tocopherol) - Formation of RBC. Vitamin D (Calciferol) - Formation of strong bones and teeth. Vitamin A (Retinol) - Keep eyes and skin healthy.

question: Which of the following groups represents essential amino acids ? Matriculation Level 26/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine. Amino acids are molecules that join together to form proteins, which are the building blocks of life. When proteins are digested or broken down, they yield amino acids. Histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, and valine are classified as essential amino acids, as the body cannot produce them. Therefore, they must be obtained from food.

question: Select the INCORRECT statement with regards to vitamins. SSC CHSL Tier II 02/11/2023

options.C: Some bacteria in the gut do not
options.D: Most of the vitamins cannot get

solution.correct_answer: C. Some bacteria in the gut do not
solution.explanation: Gut bacteria helps in supplying essential nutrients, synthesizing vitamin K, aiding in the digestion of cellulose. Vitamins A, D, E and K are fat-soluble and vitamins C and B (complex group vitamins) are water- soluble.

question: Which essential micronutrient plays a clear role in the synthesis, storage and secretion of insulin in the hexameric form as well as in the conformational integrity of insulin? SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Zinc. Micronutrients are vitamins and minerals needed by the body in very small amounts. Role of some micronutrients in our body : Fluoride inhibits the initiation and progression of dental caries (tooth decay) and stimulates new bone formation. Selenium (Se) plays a critical role in reproduction, thyroid hormone metabolism, DNA synthesis, and protection from oxidative damage and infection. Phosphorus is a component of bones, teeth, DNA, and RNA.

question: Which of the following was the first B vitamin discovered in 1897 that is essential in amino acid and carbohydrate metabolism and is active in energy production reactions ? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Thiamine. Casimir Funk is considered as the 'Father of vitamin therapy'. Vitamin B : B1 (thiamin), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B5 (pantothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B7 (biotin), B9 (folic acid), B12 (cobalamin). Fat-soluble Vitamins : A, D, E, and K. Water-Soluble Vitamins - B and C.

question: What is the most important health benefit of Vitamin D ? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.correct_answer: A. Strengthening of bones and muscles
solution.explanation: Vitamin D (Calciferol) : Source- Oily fish, egg yolks, red meat, etc. Deficiency Diseases - Rickets. Symptoms- weak and painful bones, Deformities in teeth, Pain in the bones.

question: The food component present in sugar is: SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Carbohydrates. Sugar molecules found in foods and drinks. The body breaks down carbohydrates into

question: Milk, seafood, nuts and whole grains contain high amounts of which mineral that supports bone health and our body's repair process? SSC MTS 05/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Phosphorus. Other Minerals found in Milk : Calcium, Magnesium, Potassium, Selenium and Zinc. Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is absent in Milk. Minerals and their sources : Iron - Spinach, dry nuts and seeds, Legumes (chickpeas and lentils). Zinc - Pumpkin seeds, Eggs, Whole Grains.

question: What is the monomer unit of glycogen? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Glucose (C6H12O6). Glycogen : The carbohydrates are stored in the animal body as glycogen. Also known as animal starch because its structure is similar to amylopectin and is rather more highly branched. It is present in the liver, muscles and brain. When the body needs glucose, enzymes break the glycogen down to glucose. Found in yeast and fungi. Fructose - It is a natural monosaccharide found in fruits, honey and vegetables.

question: Which essential amino acid is necessary for the production of our brain’s chemical messengers including melatonin, dopamine, noradrenaline and thyroxine? SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid to make proteins and other vital molecules such as neurotransmitters and hormones. Leucine amino acids can be used by skeletal muscle to give energy during exercise. Tryptophan is an amino acid needed for normal growth in infants and for the production and maintenance of the body's proteins, muscles, enzymes, and neurotransmitters.

question: Which of the following is the correct match of column-A with column-B? Column-A (Nutrients) Column-B (Source) i. Protein rich food. a. Wheat ii. Fat rich food b. Lemon iii. Carbohydrate rich food c. Egg white iv. Vitamin C rich food d. Butter and cheese SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (1st shift)

options.A: i - c, ii - a, iii - b, iv - d
options.B: i - c, ii - d, iii - b, iv - a
options.C: i - c, ii - d, iii - a, iv - b
options.D: i - d, ii - c, iii - b, iv - a

solution.correct_answer: C. i - c, ii - d, iii - a, iv - b

Three types of carbohydrates in food - Fiber, Sugar, and Starch. Iron - It is a constituent of our red blood cells whose function is to carry oxygen from our lungs to organs, muscles, and cells.

question: Which of the following vitamins helps to keep our skin and eyes healthy? SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Vitamin A. Deficiency Diseases - Night blindness, Irregular growth of teeth.

question: Which among the following vitamins influences iron absorption? SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Vitamin C (Water soluble). Scientific name : Ascorbic acid (C6H8O6) or ascorbate. It acts as an antioxidant and helps wound healing. It also helps in the formation of collagen. It is used to purify water after it has been Iodine - treated.

question: Which of the following vitamins helps our body to use calcium for bones and teeth? SSC MTS 19/06/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Vitamin D (Calciferol) - It helps prevent Osteoporosis (a disease that thins and weakens the bones and makes them brittle and more likely to break). Source - Oily fish, egg yolks, red meat, etc.

question: Which of the following pairs of 'mineral - source' is correct ? I. Vitamin A - Papaya II. Iron - Spinach SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Both I and II. Vitamin A - Milk, Eggs, Fish, Butter, Fortified Margarine, Cheese, Green & Yellow fruits and Vegetables, etc. Vitamin E - Meats, Poultry, Eggs, Vegetable oils, Nuts, Olives, Tomatoes, etc. Zinc - Liver, Eggs, Cereals and Seafood.

question: Which among the following vitamins is known as Niacin ? SSC CHSL 15/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Vitamin B3. Niacin is the generic name for nicotinic acid (pyridine - 3-carboxylic acid), nicotinamide (niacinamide or pyridin - 3 - carboxamide).

question: Match the columns. Nutrients Examples a. Protein i. Calcium, Phosphorous b. Carbohydrate ii. Cholesterol c. Fat iii. Glucose d. Minerals iv. Myosin SSC CGL Tier II (07/03/2023)

solution.explanation: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i. Carbohydrate : It consists of sugar, starch, and fiber. Two types - Simple Carbohydrates (Monosaccharides, Disaccharides, Oligosaccharides) and Complex Carbohydrate. Fat - It is a macronutrient essential for energy storage, insulation, and the absorption of certain vitamins.

question: Nuts, vegetable oil and fish are rich sources of__________. SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Omega-3. Most common forms of carbohydrates are sugars, fibers and starches. Minerals which are essential for health : iron, calcium, magnesium, zinc, potassium etc.

question: Which of the following pairs of minerals – need is correct? I. Iron – formation of hemoglobin II. Sodium – proper functioning of thyroid SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Only I. Iodine is needed to make a hormone called thyroxine. Biological Importance of Sodium : For the generation of nerve impulses, For maintenance of electrolyte balance and fluid balance, For heart activities and certain metabolic functions.

question: Which amino acid is essential for healthy skin and teeth, as it is a component of tooth enamel, collagen and elastin? Graduate Level 01/08/2022 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Threonine used in the biosynthesis of proteins. Leucine is an essential amino acid for protein synthesis. Arginine is used for the treatment of heart and blood vessel conditions including congestive heart failure (CHF), chest pain, high blood pressure, etc. Phenylalanine is used for a disorder that causes white patches to develop on the skin (vitiligo).

question: Which of the following is a micronutrient, and plays a role in cell division, cell growth, wound healing and the breakdown of carbohydrates? Higher Secondary 03/08/2022 (Shift - 4)

solution.explanation: Zn. Functions of Macronutrients in Plants : Nitrogen (required in large amounts, taken in the form of ions, required for the division of cells), Phosphorus (a constituent of cell membranes), Magnesium (involved in the activation of enzymes in respiration and photosynthesis and helps in the synthesis of DNA and RNA), Sulfur (an important constituent of amino acids, coenzymes, and vitamins), Potassium (required for the opening and closing of stomata).

question: Which is a major essential lipophilic (fat-soluble) vitamin required for the protection of cell membranes and the formation of red blood cells (RBCs)? SSC CHSL 10/06/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Vitamin E (Tocopherol) is a nutrient that's important to vision, reproduction, and the health of blood, brain and skin.

question: When the breakdown of food (glucose) occurs without the use of oxygen, it is called: SSC MTS 18/10/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Anaerobic respiration. Aerobic respiration - The process by which organisms use oxygen to turn fuel, such as fats and sugars, into chemical energy. Nutrition in Plants

question: Which of the following causes enlargement and extension growth of cells ? SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Turgor pressure. Pressure potential is controlled by solute potential (when solute potential decreases, pressure potential increases) and the opening and closing of stomata. Osmotic pressure is the minimum pressure which needs to be applied to a solution to prevent the inward flow of its pure solvent across a semipermeable membrane. Imbibition is a special type of diffusion that takes place when liquid is absorbed by solids-colloids causing an increase in volume.

question: Identify a carbohydrate but does not fit into the definition. SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Rhamnose (C6H12O5). Carbohydrates are primarily produced by plants and form a very large group of naturally occurring organic compounds. Some common examples of carbohydrates are cane sugar, glucose, starch, etc. Most of them have a general formula, Cx(H2O)y.

question: Which protein is found in grains? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Gluten. It is a protein naturally found in grains like wheat, barley, and rye. Proteins are large biomolecules made of long chains of amino acids, which are the building blocks of life. Digestion of proteins yields amino acids. Out of 20 amino acids, 9 are essential : phenylalanine, valine, tryptophan, threonine, isoleucine, methionine, histidine, leucine, and lysine. Newly discovered amino acids include selenocysteine and pyrrolysine.

question: What is pro-vitamin A or the anti-cancer compound present in carrots called? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Beta - carotene. It is a yellow-orange pigment found in fruits and vegetables. It converts to Vitamin A in the body, supporting healthy vision, immune function, and skin. As an antioxidant, it protects cells from damage, reducing cancer and heart disease risk. Food sources include carrots, sweet potatoes, dark leafy greens, and squash.

question: Garlic is a good source of : SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: manganese (Mn) and selenium (Se) are essential micronutrients that are important elements of cell metabolism. Garlic is a valuable source of macro and microelements, especially potassium, calcium, magnesium, phosphorus, ferrum, manganese, selenium, vanadium, copper and zinc. The characteristic odour of garlic is due to a sulphur compound.

question: On which of the following components of chloroplast is chlorophyll arranged ? Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Thylakoids. Chloroplasts contain the thylakoid membrane which is the site of photosynthesis. The thylakoid membrane contains light-absorbing pigments called the chlorophyll. The thylakoids are arranged in stacks termed grana. The space limited by the inner membrane of the chloroplast is called the stroma. The chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and carotenoid pigments which are responsible for trapping light energy essential for photosynthesis.

question: Compounds like gingerol, paradol, shogaols and zingerone are: Graduate Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: Antimicrobial compounds found in ginger. Gingerol is derived from ginger (Zingiber officinale Roscoe), which also belongs to the Zingiberaceae family. Ginger has multiple bioactive constituents including gingerols, shogaols, zingerone, paradol and gingerdiol. Gingerols possess an alkyl moiety which imparts anti-oxidative potential to it.

question: Which natural bioactive water - soluble phenolic compound is present in Fruits, vegetables and grains with red, purple, blue or black hues ? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Anthocyanin (Pigment found in plants). They’re part of a larger category of plant-based chemicals called flavonoids. Foods with high anthocyanin : Fruits - Pomegranates, Black plums, Cherries, black and red grapes etc; Vegetables - Red cabbage, Red onions, Purple corn etc; Legumes and Rice - Black rice, Black beans etc. Coumarins - colourless crystalline solid, sweet odor, bitter taste. Quercetin - bitter flavor, used in dietary supplements, beverages and foods. Naringenin - Anti-obesity, anti-diabetic flavonoid.

question: Which of the following nutrients is available mainly in apples? SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: K (Potassium). Potassium-rich fruits and vegetables : Bananas, oranges, cantaloupe, apricots, grapefruit (some dried fruits, such as prunes, raisins, and dates, are also high in potassium). Malic acid : Found primarily in apples. It is a dicarboxylic acid that is also present in grapes, wine and rhubarb.

question: Which of the following grains contain oryzenin ? SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Rice - A source of protein and contains various vitamins, such as thiamin and niacin, and minerals, such as zinc and phosphorus. Oryzenin - A rice glutelin, is an important constituent of rice protein. Glutelin comprises the major protein fraction of the rice grain and constitutes up to 80% of the total protein. Wheat contains protein, B vitamins, dietary fiber, and phytochemicals. Soyabean is high in protein and contains vitamin K1, folate, copper, manganese, phosphorus, and thiamine.

question: What happens to the guard cells when water flows into them? SSC CGL 27/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Stomatal pores open. Guard cells - They are specialized plant cells in the epidermis of leaves, stems and other organs that are used to control gas exchange. It is a kidney shaped cell that surrounds the stomata. It contains chloroplasts, which are not present in other epidermal cells. Function - To open and close the stomata, help regulate transpiration, and protect the stomatal pore.

question: Plants that are adapted to live under plenty of sunlight are called : Graduate Level 28/06/2023 (Shift - 3)

solution.explanation: Heliophytes. Examples - Sunflowers, thyme, white clover, soft velcro, mullein. Xerophytes - A group of plants that are adapted to survive in arid regions like desert and snow - covered areas. Example - Cacti, pineapple. Pteridophytes - That plants have a vascular system and reproduce through spores. Example - Whisk Fern, Dicksonia, Selaginella. Neophytes - A plant which is not native to a geographical region and was introduced in recent history. Example - Sweet flag, small balsam, cranberries.

question: The leaves have a green pigment called ____________, which helps leaves to capture the energy from the sunlight. SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Chlorophyll - Element present in chlorophyll is magnesium. Cytoplasm - The fluid inside the cell. It functions as a cellular metabolism, transport, and storage medium while providing structural support and facilitating signal transduction within the cell. Cladophyll - Shoot system in which leaves do not develop. Xanthophylls are yellow pigments that are one of the important divisions of the carotenoid group.

question: Which plant tissue is responsible for the transportation of water and minerals from the soil to the stems and leaves? SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Xylem. Xylem and phloem are the two vascular tissues that are responsible for the transport of substances in plants. Phloem helps in the bidirectional transport of food.

question: The mode of nutrition in which organisms make food themselves from simple substances is called ________. SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Autotrophic nutrition. Examples - Plants, algae and some bacterias. Heterotrophic nutrition - Depends upon plants or other organisms for nutrition. Examples - Humans, animals, Cuscuta (Amarbel). Saprotrophic nutrition - This mode of nutrition in which organisms take in nutrients from dead and decaying matter. Examples - Fungi, yeast, and several bacteria. Phototrophic nutrition - Organisms that can obtain nutrition using light. Examples - Green plants, blue-green algae.

question: Plants require nutrients for their growth which can be supplied through _______ . SSC MTS 15/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Soil, water and air. Three elements (carbon, oxygen and hydrogen) are essential to plant growth. Soil - Supplies not only minerals but also harbours nitrogen - fixing bacteria, and other microbes, holds water, supplies air to the roots and acts as a matrix that stabilises the plant.

question: Water comes out of the leaves in the form of vapour by a process called ______. SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Transpiration. Three types of

question: The broad, green part of the leaf is called . SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Lamina. The venation of leaves is the process of arrangement of veins and veinlets. They are crucial for both systemic and pulmonary circulation. The middle part of the vein of lamina is called the midrib. Petiole (mesopodium) - Lifts the lamina above the level of the stem.

question: The green plants in a terrestrial ecosystem capture about _______ percent of the energy of sunlight that falls on their leaves and convert it into food energy. SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: 1. Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants produce carbohydrates by absorbing carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight in the presence of chlorophyll and liberating chemical energy. This energy is converted into chemical energy as food.

question: Which nutrient is chlorella rich in ? SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Protein. Chlorella is known as space alga. It is used for the consumption of carbon dioxide provided by the astronauts and the production of oxygen in the spacecraft.

question: Iron, iodine and zinc can be considered as which of the following? SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Micronutrients are nutrients that are required by the body in lesser amounts for its growth and development. Examples - Magnesium, vitamin B6, vitamin C, vitamin E, etc. Non-essential nutrients can be synthesized in the body in sufficient quantities for normal functioning. They can be obtained from food as well. Examples : Alanine , Arginine, Asparagine, Aspartic acid, etc.

question: Which of the following pairs of plastids- thing stored is NOT correct? I. Amyloplasts - oils and fats II. Aleuroplasts - carbohydrates SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Evening)

options.C: Neither I nor II (d) Only II

solution.correct_answer: C. Neither I nor II (d) Only II
solution.explanation: Plastids are found in plants and algae. Functions : perform photosynthesis, attract pollinators, restore total leaf protein and synthesize starch along with the storage of proteins, fats, and oils. Types of Plastids - Chloroplasts (used for photosynthesis), Chromoplasts (used for pigment synthesis and storage), and Leucoplasts (non-pigmented plastids that can sometimes differentiate).

question: How is food stored in brown algae? SSC CHSL 30/05/2022 (Evening)

options.B: In the form of complex carbohydrates
options.C: In the form of complex lipids
options.D: In the form of oil droplets

solution.correct_answer: B. In the form of complex carbohydrates
solution.explanation: Brown algae store their food primarily in the form of complex carbohydrates. The two main storage forms are laminarin (a polysaccharide) and mannitol (a sugar alcohol). These compounds serve as energy reserves for the algae and are utilized during periods of low light or other environmental stress.

question: Pneumatophores are specialised ______ in hydrophytes. SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Roots. Hydrophytes are aquatic plants that are especially suited for living in aquatic environments. Examples - Lotus (Nelumbo), Vallisneria, Potamogeton, Salvinia, hydrilla, water hyacinths etc.

question: Which of the following does NOT figure among the main functions of the root system of a plant ? SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Evening)

options.A: Supply of food to plant parts
options.B: Providing a proper anchorage to the
options.C: Absorption of water from the soil`
options.D: Absorption of minerals from the soil

solution.correct_answer: A. Supply of food to plant parts
solution.explanation: Supply of food to the plant parts. The main function of the root system is to transport water and minerals to the plant. Food is transported by phloem tissue in the vascular system of plants.

question: Which of the following plant hormones regulates growth, particularly by stimulating cell elongation in stems? SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Auxin. Ethylene is the only plant hormone in gaseous form that regulates fruit ripening in plants. Cytokinin promotes cell division in plant roots and shoots. Osteopenia is a condition that occurs when the body doesn't make new bone as quickly as it reabsorbs old bone.

solution.explanation: Mercury poisoning. The inhalation of mercury vapour can produce harmful effects on the nervous, digestive and immune systems, lungs and kidneys, and may be fatal.

question: Which of the following animals can change their gender during their lifespan SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Snail. Most land snails are hermaphrodites, meaning they have both male and female reproductive organs. They are able to produce sperm and eggs while mating with a partner. The male reproductive organ of the snail can never fertilize the female genitals of the snail. Animals who can change their sex during their life : Clownfish, Bearded dragons, Banana slugs.

question: In a dihybrid cross between two heterozygous fruit flies with brown bodies and red eyes (BbEe BbEe), what × will be the probability of getting BBEE genotype ? SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: 1/16. Each parent can produce four types of gametes: BE, Be, bE, and be, with equal probability (1/4 each). To obtain the BBEE genotype, the offspring must receive the B and E alleles from both parents. The probability of getting BB from Bb × Bb cross is 1/4, and the probability of getting EE from Ee × Ee cross is also 1/4. Therefore, the combined probability of getting BBEE is (1/4) * (1/4) = 1/16.

question: In honey bees, _____ SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)

options.A: males are haploid and females are
options.B: males are tetraploid and females are
options.C: males are diploid and females are
options.D: males are triploid and females are

solution.correct_answer: A. males are haploid and females are
solution.explanation: males are haploid and females are diploid. The females are diploid having 32 chromosomes and males are haploid, i.e., having 16 chromosomes. This is called a haplodiploid sex determination system and has special characteristic features such as the males produce sperms by mitosis, they do not have father and thus cannot have sons, but have a grandfather and can have grandsons.

question: Identify an organism that exhibits metagenesis. SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (3rd shift)

question: The stage of the embryo in which all the body parts can be identified is called _________ . SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Afternoon)

Ovulation - A phase of the female menstrual cycle that involves the release of an egg (ovum) from one of the ovaries. Zygote - A fertilized egg cell that results from the union of a female gamete (egg, or ovum) with a male gamete (sperm).

question: The transformation of the larva into an adult through drastic change is called ___________. SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Metamorphosis - A biological process involving an abrupt change in the animal's body structure due to cell growth and differentiation. The new individuals which are born from the eggs continue to grow till they become adults. In some animals, the young ones may look very different from the adults. Metamorphosis cycle has four stages : Egg, Larva, Pupa and Adult. Examples : Butterflies, moths, frogs, toads, etc.

question: How many arteries are there in an umbilical cord? SSC CGL 13/08/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Two. The umbilical cord is a tube that connects the mother with the baby in her womb during pregnancy. It normally contains two arteries (the umbilical arteries ) and one vein ( the umbilical vein).

question: ______ is the ability of a single cell to produce a fertile, adult individual. SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Morning).

question: The phenomenon whereby the female gamete undergoes development to form new organisms without fertilisation in some organisms like honey bees, some lizards and birds is called : SSC CPO 25/11/2020 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Parthenogenesis is a form of reproduction in which an egg can develop into an embryo without being fertilized by a sperm. question: Which of the following statements best defines the monoecious? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)

options.A: A flower with both androecium and

solution.correct_answer: A. A flower with both androecium and
solution.explanation: Monoecious plants bear both purely male and purely female flowers. Examples include castor, cucumber, and maize. In contrast, dioecious plants have male and female flowers on separate plants, such as papaya.

question: Which of the following is NOT a component of a flower ? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Spines. They are modified leaves or stems that serve as a defense mechanism in plants, particularly in cacti and succulents. Androecium : The male reproductive part of the flower, consisting of stamens (filaments and anthers). Corolla : The collective term for the petals of a flower. Calyx : The collective term for the sepals (green,

question: By which of the following methods do red algae reproduce? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Fragmentation. Algae reproduce through vegetative, asexual, and sexual methods: Vegetative Reproduction: This occurs by fragmentation, where each fragment develops into a new thallus. Asexual Reproduction: This involves the production of various types of spores, with zoospores being the most common. Sexual Reproduction: in algae involves the fusion of gametes, which can be isogamous (fusion of similar gametes) or anisogamous (fusion of dissimilar gametes), leading to the formation of zygotes that develop into new individuals.

question: Which types of gametes are found in Spirogyra? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Isogamous and non - flagellated. Reproduction in Spirogyra: Spirogyra, a genus of green algae, reproduces sexually through isogamous (similar in size) and non-flagellated gametes. Two adjacent cells form a conjugation tube, allowing the male gametangium's contents to move into the female gametangium, resulting in the formation of a zygote.

question: Which of the following is a part of apical meristem found in roots. SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Protoderm. Apical meristem is the region of plant tissue where growth occurs, and it's found in both roots and shoots. In roots, the apical meristem consists of three primary meristematic tissues: Protoderm (outermost layer) - Gives rise to the epidermis. Ground meristem (middle layer) - Gives rise to the cortex and endodermis. Procambium (innermost layer) - Gives rise to the vascular tissue.

question: The reproduction process in which only a single parent is involved is called ___________. SSC MTS 11/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Asexual reproduction - Observed in both multicellular and unicellular organisms and does not involve any kind of gamete fusion. Offspring are genetically similar to their parents. Different types : Binary Fission - Cell divide (Archaea and Bacteria). Budding (Bacteria, yeast, corals, flatworms, Jellyfish and sea anemones). Fragmentation (Spirogyra, Planaria). Vegetative Propagation (Potato tubers, runners, onion). Sporogenesis (Plants, Algae, Fungi).

question: The innermost part of a flower is called the _______. SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Pistil (the female reproductive part of a flower). It has three parts which are stigma, style, and ovary. Petals (collectively known as the corolla) are modified leaves that surround the reproductive parts of flowers. Stamen is the male part of the flower. Generally, it is shaped like a bowling pin and is located in the flower's center. It consists of Anther and Filament.

question: Which of the following is not an asexual form of reproduction in plants? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Pollination. Flowering plants reproduce sexually through a process called pollination. It is the act of transferring pollen grains from the male anther of a flower to the female stigma. The two types of pollination are self-pollination (if pollen is transferred to it from any flower of the same plant) and cross-pollination ( if the pollen comes from a flower of a different plant).

question: Which part of a flower is the sticky surface at the top of the pistil, it traps and holds the pollen? SSC MTS 07/10/2021 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Stigma. It traps and holds the pollen. During the process of pollination, pollen moves from the male parts to the female parts i.e stigma where pollen germinates.

solution.explanation: Lysosomes. These organelles are filled with hydrolytic enzymes that break down biological polymers like proteins, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and lipids. question: The Krebs cycle of aerobic respiration is carried out within which of the following cell organelles? SSC MTS 30/10/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Mitochondria. Mitochondria are organelles that are known as the "powerhouses" of a cell because they produce energy. The Krebs cycle is also known as the citric acid cycle or the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. It's a central part of cellular respiration, and it harvests energy from acetyl molecules in the form of ATP.

question: Which of the following pairs is INCORRECT regarding the grade of organisation and its example ? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)

question: Which of the following Illustrations shows the mitochondrion’s structural details? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: b. The mitochondrion is a double - membraned, rod - shaped structure found in both plant and animal cells. Its size ranges from 0.5 to 1.0 micrometre in diameter. The structure comprises an outer membrane, an inner membrane, and a gel-like material called the matrix.

question: Which cell organelle is defined as the small round organelle that undergoes oxidation reaction to produce hydrogen peroxide? www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Biology SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

question: Which of the following is an example of prokaryotic cells? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Bacteria. Prokaryotic cells lack a well-organized nucleus, with their genetic material consisting of a single DNA molecule located in the cytoplasm. Examples of prokaryotic cells include blue-green algae. Yeast is an example of a eukaryotic unicellular fungi cell.

question: Which of the following illustrations is related to chloroplasts? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: c. Plastids are classified into chloroplasts, chromoplasts, and leucoplasts, based on their pigments. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll and carotenoids, crucial for capturing light energy in photosynthesis. Chromoplasts have fat-soluble carotenoid pigments (like carotene and xanthophylls) that give plants yellow, orange, or red colors. question: In the context of cell division, which chromosomal behaviour takes place at the leptotene stage? SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Chromosomes begin to condense. The leptotene stage is the first of five substages in prophase I of meiosis, a specialized cell division process that reduces the number of chromosomes by half. During this stage, chromosomes manifest as long, thin threads. Meiosis produces haploid gametes in sexually reproducing organisms, contrasting with mitosis, where a single cell divides into two identical daughter cells. Mitosis comprises several stages: Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, and Telophase.

question: Which of the following enzymes are essential of DNA replication in an animal cell ? SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: The essential enzymes for DNA replication are: Topoisomerase: Relaxes the DNA molecule by cutting and rejoining it, reducing tension and supercoiling. DNA primase: Adds RNA primers to the template strands at specific regions, providing a starting point for DNA synthesis. DNA polymerase: Synthesizes new DNA strands by adding nucleotides to the primers, matching the base pairing rules. DNA ligase: Seals the gaps between the newly synthesized DNA segments, forming a continuous strand.

question: What do you mean by semiconservative DNA replication ? SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (2nd shift)

options.B: RNA is dependent on DNA for the

solution.correct_answer: C. After the completion of replication,
solution.explanation: Semiconservative DNA replication refers to the process by which DNA is replicated, resulting in two daughter DNA molecules, each containing: One parental strand (the original template strand) and One newly synthesized strand (created during replication).

question: In a symport: SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Symport: Two or more molecules move together in the same direction across the membrane using the same transport protein. Antiport: Two or more molecules move in opposite directions across the membrane. Uniport: A single molecule moves across the membrane independently of other molecules.

question: The cell wall of bacteria is made up of: SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift)

Peptones are products of protein digestion used as nutrient sources in microbial culture media, not structural components of cell walls.

question: Who was the first person to conduct a systematic study of chromosomes during division and called this process mitosis ? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Walther Flemming. He was a German biologist and a founder of cytogenetics. His key discoveries - Chromatin, Chromosomes. Thomas Hunt Morgan received the 1933 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discoveries concerning the role of chromosomes in heredity.

question: What are the thin filamentous extensions that the motile bacterial cells have from their cell wall called? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift) www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Biology

solution.explanation: Flagella. The bacterial flagella are long (3 to 12 µm), filamentous surface appendages about 12 to 30 nm in diameter. question: What is the fourth step in mitosis where non-kinetochore spindle fibres lengthen and elongate the cell? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Anaphase. Mitosis is divided into four stages namely prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase. Prophase the chromosomes condense and centrosomes move to opposite sides of the nucleus, initiating formation of the mitotic spindle. Metaphase is a stage during the process of cell division (mitosis or meiosis). Telophase is the last phase of mitosis before cytokinesis, and is where sister chromatids separate, and the new nuclei are formed.

question: Identify the organelle present in plant cells that is not there in an animal cell. SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)

question: Identify an organelle found both in eukaryotic as well as prokaryotic. SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)

They are about 15 nm by 20 nm in size and are made of two subunits - 50S and 30S units which when present together form 70S prokaryotic ribosomes. Ribosomes are the site of protein synthesis.

question: Which chromosome is involved in the production of 'masked' mRNAs for early development? Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Mitochondria. Apoptosis, or programmed cell death, is a process where cells die through a series of molecular steps. question: Chromosomes found in the salivary glands of Drosophila are : Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 4)

question: What are ribosomes made up of? Higher Secondary 26/06/2024 (Shift - 2)

solution.explanation: Proteins and RNA. Ribosomes are cell organelles involved in protein synthesis, earning them the name 'protein factories.' They consist of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and approximately 40 to 80 proteins, which provide structural support. Ribosomes have two subunits: large and small. The subunits remain separate when not synthesizing proteins and come together during the process of protein synthesis.

question: Most centrioles have a _________ structure of triple microtubules, which are present in pairs and arranged orthogonally after duplication. SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)

question: Which cellular structure controls cell motility, adhesion, and polarity at interphase, and facilitates the organisation of spindle poles during mitosis ? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Centrosomes - Membrane - free organelles that serve as main microtubule-organizing centers in distinct eukaryotic lineages.

question: What is the percentage of proteins in the cell membrane? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 40-60%. Cell membrane (plasma membrane) - It separates the interior of the cell from the outside environment. It is composed primarily of fatty-acid-based lipids and proteins. The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all forms of life. It was discovered by a British scientist, Robert Hooke in 1665.

question: What do you call the fluid matrix filling in the cell ? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Cytoplasm. It is composed of water, salts, and various organic molecules. Golgi bodies (Golgi apparatus) - It helps process and package proteins and lipid molecules, especially proteins destined to be exported from the cell.

question: The main function of centriole is: SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)

options.B: to help plant cell for multiplication
options.C: to help cell division in animal cell
options.D: to maintain rigidity in plant cell

solution.correct_answer: C. to help cell division in animal cell
solution.explanation: Centrosome - An organelle containing two cylindrical structures called centrioles. Centrioles form the basal body of cilia or flagella, and spindle fibres that give rise to spindle apparatus during cell division in animal cells. It plays a role in organizing microtubules that serve as the cell's skeletal system. They help determine the locations of the nucleus and other organelles within the cell.

question: During which phase of the cell www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Biology cycle does metabolic changes assemble the cytoplasmic material required for mitosis and cytokinesis? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: G2 phase. The different phases of a cell cycle include : Interphase (This phase includes the G1 phase, S phase and the G2 phase), M phase (This is the mitotic phase and is divided into prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase) and Cytokinesis (In this phase the cytoplasm of the cell divides). S phase - Cell synthesises a complete copy of the DNA. M phase - Cell divides its copied DNA and cytoplasm to make two new cells. G1 phase - First gap phase, the cell grows physically larger.

question: How big are red blood cells in diameter ? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 7.5 μm. Red blood cells (erythrocytes) - It is rich in hemoglobin, an iron rich molecule that can bind oxygen and also imparts red color to the blood. RBC is produced in the bone marrow (erythropoiesis process) and has a life cycle of 120 days. RBC is recycled by macrophages. RBC Disorders: Anemia (Lower than normal RBC), Polycythemia (Excess of RBC), Sickle Cell Disease (Genetic Disorder causes RBCs to take on a crescent shape), Thalassemia (Genetic blood disorders that result in abnormal hemoglobin production).

question: What is the length of a bacterial cell? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 3 to 5 μm. Bacteria are single - celled microorganisms. Bacterial cell - Prokaryotic cells, lacking well - defined nuclei and membrane-bound organelles, and with chromosomes composed of a single closed DNA circle. Length of cells in organisms : Human - 20-30 micrometres. Plants - 10 to 100 micrometers.

question: What do you call a Glycocalyx that is a loose sheath type? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Slime layer. It is a type of glycocalyx that is loosely organized and not firmly attached to the cell wall. It is a thin, diffuse layer of polysaccharides and proteins that surrounds some bacterial cells. The slime layer can help bacteria adhere to surfaces and protect them from dehydration. The glycocalyx is a dense, gel-like meshwork that surrounds the cell, constituting a physical barrier for any object to enter the cell.

question: Which process is sometimes called "reduction division" because it reduces the number of chromosomes to half the normal number to form sperm and eggs? SSC MTS 06/09/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Meiosis. The cell cycle is divided into two basic phases : Interphase and M Phase (Mitosis phase). The M Phase represents the phase when the actual cell division or mitosis occurs and the interphase represents the phase between two successive M phases (Cytokinesis and Karyokinesis).

question: By what name are the flat membrane-enclosed sacs present in the Golgi apparatus known? SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Cisternae - It is a membrane-bound cell organelle consisting of a series of flattened membranous sacs that look like stacked pouches. Organelles present in cells - Nucleus, Endoplasmic Reticulum, Mitochondria, Centriole, Ribosome, Vacuole, Lysosome.

question: Which cell found in the bone marrow acts as a repair system for the body ? SSC MTS 11/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Stem cells - Unspecialised cells which divide to produce two daughter cells, one of which remains a stem cell and the other one becomes differentiated. The major sources of stem cells are embryos and adult tissues (adult stem cells). Stem cells are characterised into three types depending on their potency : Unipotent cells, pluripotent cells and multipotent cells.

question: During cell division, the formation of a new cell wall is followed by the accumulation of: SSC MTS 13/09/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Phragmoplast is a plant cell specialized cylindrical structure formed during late cytokinesis. Periplasm - The space is the area between the cell wall and the plasma membrane. The term Protoplast was introduced by Hanstein. It refers to the entire cell, excluding the cell wall. The Peristome is a teeth-like projection that surrounds the mouth of the capsule in most of the members of Bryidae (Mosses) of bryophytes.

question: Which part of a cell converts nutrients into energy ? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Mitochondria - Double membrane-bound cell organelles present in most eukaryotic organisms (such as animals, plants and fungi). Chromosome - A thread - like microscopic structure formed by coiling of DNA packaged with protein containing all genetic material of an organism.

question: Which cell analysis technique is used to rapidly analyse single cells or particles as they flow through single or multiple lasers while suspended in a buffered salt-based solution? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Flow cytometry - It is a laser-based technique used to detect and analyze the chemical and physical characteristics of cells or particles, It is to evaluate bone marrow, peripheral blood and other fluids in your body. Mass spectroscopy - Used to identify and quantify molecules by measuring their mass-to-charge ratio. Electrochemical analysis - Used to measure the electrical properties of cells or particles. Multiple displacement amplification - Used to amplify DNA.

question: The division of cytoplasm is known as: SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Cytokinesis : It is a physical process which divides the cytoplasm of a parental cell into two daughter cells. Karyokinesis : Division of the nucleus

question: Which of the following cell organelles can make copies of themselves ? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Mitochondria (Powerhouse of cells). Vacuole - A membrane-bound cell organelle. In animal cells, vacuoles are generally small and help sequester waste products.

question: Which type of haploid unicellular eukaryote cells has a diameter of ~10 μm, and about half of their volume is occupied by cup-shaped chloroplasts ? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Chlamydomonas : Single -celled green algae found in both freshwater and marine habitats. It reproduces asexually by zoospores, hypnospores. Hydrodictyon (water net) : green algae, found in freshwater. Ulva (sea lettuce) : Green algae, found in marine environments. Oedogonium : Green algae, found in freshwater ponds, streams, and even in some terrestrial environments with high humidity.

question: Which cell organelles are known as cell's post office ? SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Golgi apparatus. It is responsible for processing and packaging proteins and lipid molecules, particularly those destined for export.

question: Which of the following cells are found in the liver of mammals? SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Kupffer cells. They are resident liver macrophages and maintain liver functions. They are the first innate immune cells and protect the liver from bacterial infections. Purkinje cells - They are a unique type of neuron, specific to the cerebellar cortex. Microglia cells are resident cells of the brain that regulate brain development, maintenance of neuronal networks, and injury repair. Sensory cells - They occur in specialized organs such as the eyes, ears, nose, and mouth, as well as internal organs.

question: In a plant, ______ is present in the middle lamella, primary cell and secondary walls and accumulates in the initial stages of development during cell expansion. SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Pectin (polysaccharide) - A soluble fibre found in fruits. Chitin - A long chain polymer of N -acetylglucosamine, an amide derivative of glucose, forms a long chain polymer. Present in cell walls and septa of all pathogenic fungi and cyst walls of pathogenic amoebae. Gelatin - A food ingredient found in soups, broths, sauces, gummy candies, marshmallows, cosmetics, and medications. Alginate - Naturally occurring anionic polymer typically obtained from brown seaweed.

question: Select the correct statement. SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Bacteria do not have a nucleus or membrane-bound organelles. They have ribosomes. Fungal cells have ribosomes and a nucleus. They also have other organelles like endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, ribosomes, Golgi apparatus and vacuoles. Plant cells have ribosomes (Responsible for protein synthesis) mitochondria, nucleus, and chloroplasts (responsible for photosynthesis).

question: Which form of leucoplast specialises in oil synthesis and storage and is mainly found in the layer of cells in pollen grains that develop pollen grains? SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Elaioplasts - These are plastids that are specialized in oil synthesis and found primarily in the layer of cells. Gerontoplasts - Type of plastid formed during leaf senescence (deterioration with age), Derived from - Chloroplasts. Proteinoplasts are specialized organelles found in plant cells. Chloroplasts are organelle that contains the photosynthetic pigment chlorophyll that captures sunlight and converts it into useful energy, Found in green plants and algae.

question: Which cells, also called neurilemma cells, are the main glial cells in the PNS and play an essential role in the survival and functions of neurons? SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Schwann cells. Peripheral Nervous System - Part of your nervous system that lies outside the brain and spinal cord. Central nervous system - Includes two organs, the brain and spinal cord. Bipolar cells - One of the main retinal interneurons that provide the main pathways from photoreceptors to ganglion cells.

question: The cells having well-organized nuclei with a nuclear membrane are designated as__________ . SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Eukaryotic cells - Larger and more complex than prokaryotic cells. These possess a well-defined nucleus, enclosed within a nuclear membrane, and contain various membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, and others.

question: Which component of the cell contains the hereditary material of the cell, the DNA? SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Nucleus (Discovered by Robert Brown) - It is a membrane - bound organelle found in eukaryotic cells. It contains the cell's genetic material, including DNA, which carries the instructions for cell function and inheritance. Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) - Discovered by James Watson and Francis Crick.

question: Cells were first observed in cork by __________ in 1665. SSC MTS 03/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Robert Hooke. Edward Jenner - Discovered the smallpox vaccine in 1796. Theophrastus - The father of botany. Anton van Leeuwenhoek (Father of Microbiology) - He discovered protists and bacteria.

question: What is the jelly-like substance between the nucleus and the cell membrane called? SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Cytoplasm. It is the main area for all the activities taking place inside a cell. It is made of water, salts and proteins. Plasma is the fluid that makes up the blood and other bodily fluids.

question: Which component of the cell organelles principally performs the function of packaging materials, to be delivered either to the intra-cellular targets or secreted outside the cell? SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Golgi Apparatus (Golgi complex or Golgi body).

question: What is the major function of a cell wall? SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Morning)

options.A: It works as a storage for material
options.B: It provides shape and rigidity to the
options.C: It is responsible for cell division
options.D: It helps in synthesis of carbohydrate

solution.correct_answer: B. It provides shape and rigidity to the
solution.explanation: The cell wall in plants is composed mainly of cellulose and contains three layers in many plants. The three layers are the middle lamella, primary cell wall, and secondary cell wall. It is only found in Plant Cell.

question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a plant cell? SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Cell wall is present. Plant cells have a rigid cell wall that surrounds the cell membrane. This cell wall provides structural support and protection for the cell. Animal cells do not have a cell wall. Animal cells have lysosomes which are organelles that contain enzymes that break down cellular waste while Plant cells do not have lysosomes.

question: Plant cell have a big central ___ unlike a number of small ___ in animal cells. SSC MTS 18/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Vacuole, vacuoles. Plant cells - Eukaryotic cells that vary in several fundamental factors from other eukaryotic organisms. It is rectangular and comparatively larger than the animal cell. Tissue - A group of cells with similar structure and function. It forms a cellular organizational level, intermediate between the cells and organ system.

question: Which of the following is a complex permanent plant tissue? SSC MTS 19/06/2023 (Afternoon

solution.explanation: Xylem - It is a complex permanent tissue found in vascular plants. It is responsible for conducting water, minerals, and nutrients from the roots to the other parts of the plant. Xylem and Phloem are the Complex Permanent tissues.

question: At high doses, ________ kills cancer cells or slows their growth by damaging their DNA. Cancer cells whose DNA is damaged beyond repair, stop dividing or die. When the damaged cells die, they are broken down and removed by the body. SSC CHSL 09/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Radiation therapy. The X-ray generating methodology is applied to cancer therapy. X-rays discovered in 1895 by W. C. Roentgen. Types of radiation therapy: 1. External beam radiation therapy comes from a machine to deliver radiation. 2. Internal radiation therapy uses implants or drugs to deliver radiation inside the body.

question: ________ is the chemical process in which different types of chemical reactions are involved in controlling the living state of the cells in an organism. SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Metabolism. The circulatory system is the “transportation system” for the body, and blood serves as the transport vehicle. Respiration - Process in which organisms exchange gases between their body cells and the environment. Excretion - Process by which animals rid themselves of waste products and of the nitrogenous by-products of metabolism.

question: In Golgi apparatus, the maturing face is: SSC CGL 01/12/2022 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Concave. The Golgi cisternae are concentrically arranged near the nucleus with distinct convex cis or the forming face and concave, trans or the maturing face. The Golgi apparatus (discovered by Camillo Golgi in 1898) is located close to the nucleus and can be very large in secretory cells, where it fills almost the complete cytoplasm.

question: What is the outermost layer found in the cell envelope of the bacterial cell called? SSC CGL 02/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Glycocalyx. It is a network of polysaccharides attached to the cell wall.

question: There are ____ main types of cell division. SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 2. Types - Mitosis : The process in which cells use to make exact replicas of themselves. Mitosis is observed in almost all the body’s cells, including eyes, skin, hair, and muscle cells. Meiosis : In this type of cell division, sperm or egg cells are produced instead of identical daughter cells as in mitosis.

question: Identify an option that does NOT represent prokaryotic cells. SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Sperm. Prokaryotic cells - Do not have a true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles - single - celled microorganisms. Examples - Bacteria and Archaea, Mycoplasma (Pleuropneumonia-like organism, a genus of bacteria), Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria).

question: A group of ribosomes attached to www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Biology mRNA is known as __________. SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Polysomes. They include a piece of the genetic code that is translated by each ribosome and are employed in the synthesis of numerous copies of the same polypeptide. Polypeptide - short chains of amino acids linked by peptide bonds. Long chains of amino acids are called proteins. Polymer - materials made of long, repeating chains of molecules. Monomer - A molecule that forms the basic unit for polymers. Example - Sugar is a monomer of polymers like glycogen, starch, and cellulose.

question: An undifferentiated layer, _________is present in between the ectoderm and the endoderm. SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Mesoglea. Coelenterata and Ctenophora show the scattered pouches in between ectoderm and endoderm. Animals in which the body cavity is absent are called acoelomates, such as Platyhelminthes.

question: What happens to the decomposition rate when detritus is rich in lignin and chitin ? SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (1st Shift)

options.C: There is no movement (d) It is slower

solution.explanation: It is slower. Decomposition is faster if nitrogen and water soluble substances are present.

question: Identify the function of plasmid DNA. SSC CGL 06/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

options.A: None of the given options are correct
options.D: To help in the formation of rRNA

solution.correct_answer: C. To confer certain unique phenotypic
solution.explanation: A plasmid is a small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecule that is distinct from a cell's chromosomal DNA. Plasmids naturally exist in bacterial cells, and they also occur in some eukaryotes. Often, the genes carried in plasmids provide bacteria with genetic advantages, such as antibiotic resistance.

question: Match Column-A with Column-B Column-A Column-B i. Gl a. Cell synthesises a complete copy of the DNA ii. S b. First gap phase, the cell grows physically larger iii. G2 c. Cell begins to reorganise its contents in preparation for mitosis iv. M d. Cell divides its copied DNA and cytoplasm to make two new cells SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (2nd Shift)

options.A: i-b, ii-a, iii-c, iv-d (b) i-c, ii-a, iii-b, iv-d
options.C: i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d (d) i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c

solution.correct_answer: A. i-b, ii-a, iii-c, iv-d (b) i-c, ii-a, iii-b, iv-d
solution.explanation: i-b, ii-a, iii-c, iv-d.

question: What is the role of ribosomes of a polysome? SSC CGL 09/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. The ribosomes of a polysome
solution.explanation: The ribosomes of a polysome translate the mRNA into proteins. A ribosome is an intracellular structure made of both RNA and protein, and it is the site of protein synthesis in the cell.

question: Which of the following is a plant tissue? I. Meristematic tissue II. Permanent tissue SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Meristematic tissues are cells or groups of cells that have the ability to divide. The tissues that are completely grown and have lost the ability to divide are known as Permanent tissues. Types of Plant Tissue - Meristematic Tissue ( Apical, Intercalary, Lateral) and Permanent Tissue {Simple (Parenchyma, Collenchyma, Sclerenchyma), Complex (Xylem and Phloem)}.

question: Cells of meristematic tissue lack ________. SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Vacuoles. They are dividing rigorously so they need not store food or waste products.

question: Which of the following is NOT a type of chromosome, on the basis of the location of the centromere? SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Lophocentric. Chromosomes are bundles of tightly coiled DNA located within the nucleus of almost every cell in our body. Depending on the position of the centromere, chromosomes are categorized into the following types: Metacentric, Telocentric, Acrocentric, Submetacentric.

question: Which thin flexible barrier separates the internal environment of the cell from the extracellular fluid? SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Plasma Membrane consists of both lipids and proteins and provides protection for a cell. Lipids are fatty, wax-like molecules found in the human body and other organisms.

question: Which of the following cell organelles functions both as a passageway for intracellular transport and as a manufacturing surface? SSC MTS 08/07/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Endoplasmic Reticulum is a major site of protein synthesis and transport, protein folding, lipid and steroid synthesis, carbohydrate metabolism and calcium storage. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) are of two types : Smooth ER and Rough ER. Function of lysosomes (digestion and removal of waste).

question: In plant cell, ______ are primarily organelles in which materials such as starch, oils and protein granules are stored. SSC MTS 18/07/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Leucoplasts. The basic function of it is the storage of essential compounds such as starch, lipids, and proteins.

question: Amoeba acquires its food through the process of ______. SSC MTS 19/07/2022 (Morning) www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Biology

solution.explanation: Endocytosis is a general term describing a process by which cells absorb external material by engulfing it with the cell membrane. Exocytosis is the process by which cells move materials from within the cell into the extracellular fluid. Diffusion is the movement of molecules from an area of high concentration of the molecules to an area with a lower concentration.

question: What are the projections of varying lengths protruding out of an amoeba’s body, which can appear and disappear, known as? SSC MTS 19/07/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Pseudopodia are called the false feet as they are actually extensions of the cytoplasm or the thick liquid that is inside organisms like an Amoeba. The function of the contractile vacuole is to pump water out of the cell through a process called osmoregulation, the regulation of osmotic pressure. Paramecium is a genus of unicellular ciliated protozoa, commonly studied as a representative of the ciliate group.

question: ______ is known as the energy currency of the cell. SSC MTS 20/07/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: ATP (Adenosine triphosphate) is the source of energy for use and storage at the cellular level and has three phosphates. ADP is adenosine diphosphate and contains only two phosphate groups. DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the hereditary material in humans and almost all other organisms. Ribonucleic acid (RNA) is a nucleic acid present in all living cells.

question: Which of the following are situated in the nucleus of a cell? SSC MTS 22/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Chromosomes and genes. Each cell in the human body has 23 pairs of chromosomes (46 total chromosomes). Two of them are the X and the Y chromosome, determine sex as male or female when you are born.

question: Which cell theory proved that the quasi-fluid nature of lipids enables lateral movement of proteins within the overall bilayer? SSC CHSL 24/05/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Fluid mosaic model describes the cell membrane as a tapestry of several types of molecules (phospholipids, cholesterols, and proteins) that are constantly moving. Cell theory states that the cell is the basic functional and structural unit of all living organisms.

question: Under the electron microscope, which cell organelle is visible as either clusters or single, small dots that float freely in the cytoplasm? SSC CHSL 25/05/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Ribosome. It is an intracellular structure made of both RNA and protein, and it is the site of protein synthesis in the cell. Vesicles can be used to move molecules, secrete substances, digest materials, or regulate the pressure in the cell.

question: Identify the cell that is amoeboid in shape. SSC CHSL 26/05/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: White Blood Cell. It is also known as leukocytes, are responsible for protecting your body from infection. The basic unit of communication in the nervous system is the nerve cell (neuron). Columnar epithelial cells are elongated and column-shaped and have a height of at least four times their width.

question: In cell biology, what is a large double-membraned organelle that is sometimes referred to as the ‘central unit’ of the cell because it contains the chromosomes that bear genetic material? SSC CHSL 30/05/2022 ( Evening)

solution.explanation: Nucleus. Peroxisomes are organelles that sequester diverse oxidative reactions and play important roles in metabolism, reactive oxygen species detoxification, and signaling.

question: In animal cells, which membrane -bound cell organelles are generally smaller and help to separate waste products? SSC CHSL 31/05/2022 ( Morning)

solution.explanation: Vacuole. Cytosol is known as the matrix of the cytoplasm.

question: Identify the component found only in a eukaryotic cell. SSC CHSL 31/05/2022 ( Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Nuclear membrane. Ribosomes can be found in both prokaryote (bacteria) and eukaryote (animals and plants) cells.

question: Which is the major microtubule - organising centre (MTOC) in eukaryotic cells involved in various cellular processes, including sensory reception, locomotion, and embryogenesis? SSC CHSL 02/06/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Centrosome is a cellular structure involved in the process of cell division.

question: Which of the following is an example of active transport? SSC CHSL 03/06/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Sodium-potassium pump present on the cell membrane, which transports 3 sodium ions outside and 2 potassium ions inside of the cell per ATP. Active transport (uphill transport) transports substances against the concentration gradient from lower to higher concentration. Passive transport (Glucose transporters) are a wide group of membrane proteins that facilitate the transport of glucose across the plasma membrane.

question: Choose the correct sequence for central dogma. SSC CHSL 06/06/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: The 'Central Dogma' is the process by which the instructions in DNA are converted into a functional product. It was first proposed in 1958 by Francis Crick, discoverer of the structure of DNA. The central dogma of molecular biology: DNA →RNA →protein.

question: Which biological stain is used in histology and cytology to colour all cell nuclei red? SSC CHSL 06/06/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Safranin. It is mostly utilized for the identification of cartilage, mucin, and mast cell granules. Cresol red is a triarylmethane dye, used as an acid-base indicator, or pH indicator.

question: Match column A with column B. Column - A Column - B i. Peptidoglycan a. Cell wall of plants ii. Pectin b. Bacterial cell wall iii. Chitin c. Cell wall of fruits iv. Cellulose d. Insect cell wall SSC CHSL 07/06/2022 (Evening)

options.A: i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c (b) i-b, ii-a, iii-c, iv-d
options.C: i-b, ii-c, iii-d, iv-a (d) i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d

solution.correct_answer: C. i-b, ii-c, iii-d, iv-a (d) i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d
solution.explanation: i-b, ii-c, iii-d, iv-a. Sensory Organs

question: What is the main sense organ that virtual reality displays are aiming for SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Vision. Virtual reality (VR) aiming to create an immersive visual experience that simulates a virtual environment. While some VR systems may also incorporate audio and haptic feedback to engage the senses of hearing and touch, the main focus is on visual stimulation.

question: What is the shape of the eyeball ? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Spherical. Parts of the human eye: Vitreous humour - This is a gel-like substance which maintains the shape of the eyeball. It is also a refractive media. Anterior chamber - It contains the iris and a fluid called the aqueous humour. Pupil - It is an aperture of variable size in the centre of the iris, which regulates the amount of light entering the eyeball. Retina - It is a transparent layer forming the inner coat of the eye, it supports the choroid layer.

question: Identify the structure that controls the size of the pupil. SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Iris. Parts of the human eye: Iris is the coloured membrane behind the cornea and in the point of the lens with an aperture of variable size called pupil. Cornea - The rays of light enter this layer. Cornea accounts for two-thirds of the total optical power of the eye. Vitreous humour - This is a gel-like substance which maintains the shape of the eyeball. It is also a refractive media.

question: Which type of muscles do the uterus, iris of the eye, and bronchi contain? Matriculation Level 20/06/2024 (Shift - 1)

solution.explanation: Smooth muscles (involuntary muscles) are found in various organs and tissues that require automatic contraction and relaxation. The uterus, iris of the eye, and bronchi all contain smooth muscles. Characteristics of smooth muscles : Involuntary (not under conscious control), Non-striated (no visible striations), Found in internal organs (hollow organs). Cardiac muscles: Found exclusively in the heart, these muscles pump blood.

question: Clove is an__________ indicator. SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Olfactory. Vanilla, clove and onion are examples of olfactory indicators. Clove - Scientific name - Syzygium aromaticum. Medicinal Properties - Antioxidant, Antimicrobial, Antinociceptive, Antiviral, etc.

question: What do you call the transparent front part of the eye? SSC MTS 11/10/2021(Morning)

solution.explanation: Cornea. It covers the pupil (the opening at the centre of the eye), iris (the coloured part of the eye), and the anterior chamber of the eye (the fluid-filled inside of the eye).

question: Which of the following body parts behaves like a stretched rubber sheet? SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Evening)

question: How many chambers are there in the heart of fishes ? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

question: In which of the following plants do roots arise from parts of a plant other than the radicle ? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Monstera. Three types of roots are found in Monstera deliciosa: aerial roots, aerial roots that have entered the soil (aerial-subterranean roots), and lateral roots that form on aerial-subterranean roots (lateral - subterranean roots). The three root types differed in anatomical development and in growth. It is an example of adventitious roots, which grow from parts of the plant other than the radicle. These roots can be aerial or underground and may develop from nodes (money plant, bamboo), stem cuttings (rose), branches (banyan), or the stem base (fibrous roots in monocots).
